title: FOIA Request - Premier, Inc. (Securities and Exchange Commission)

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request - Premier, Inc. (Securities and Exchange Commission)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act and Privacy Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552. I hereby request the following records:

All records related to Premier, Inc. from from 2013 to 2023 (present day) within your agency's possession.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

In the event that fees cannot be waived, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

If you deny any part of this request, please cite each specific exemption you think justifies your refusal to release the information and notify me of appeal procedures available under the law.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statue requires.

Sincerely,

Bailey Pillon

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request - Premier, Inc. (Securities and Exchange Commission)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Please disregard this request and cease processing it. I erroneously mentioned the wrong company here.

Sincerely,

Bailey Pillon

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: FOIA Request - Premier, Inc. (Securities and Exchange Commission)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I apologize, do not disregard this request. Upon closer inspection, It was not in error.

Sincerely,

Bailey Pillon

communications.subject: Thank you for your submission
communications.communication:
Your request was successfully submitted and sent to the appropriate SEC division or office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #23-02816-FOIA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following Freedom of Information Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 6, 2023. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.  You had assigned it reference number #23-02816-FOIA.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #23-02816-FOIA
communications.communication:
Good afternoon Ms. Pillon,

Thank you for inquiring about your request.  Please be advised that I am still consulting with the SEC staff regarding your request.  We are still consulting with the staff regarding potentially responsive records relating to your FOIA request.  Once we receive a response from the SEC staff, our office will continue to process your request as expeditiously as possible.  Due to the unforeseen delays, the new estimated completion date (ECD) is December 31, 2023.  This new ECD is to ensure that the agency’s search of records is accurate, and if records are located, sufficient time to review them for responsiveness.  We do sincerely apologize for the unusually long delays.  You may continue to contact me during the interim.

Kindest Regards,

      Alysia Morrow
FOIA Research Specialist
Office of FOIA Services

OFFICE                 +1 202 551 8376
amorrowa@sec.gov<mailto:amorrowa@sec.gov>

communications.subject: Still Interested - SEC FOIA# 23-02817-FOIA
communications.communication: Dear Ms. Pillon, This concerns your FOIA request dated July 6, 2023, for records related to Premier, Inc. from 2013 to present. We sincerely apologize for the delay in responding to your FOIA request.  Our office is experiencing a backlog of FOIA requests that has impacted our ability to process your request.  Due to the passage of time, we are writing to see if you are still interested in having your FOIA request processed.  If you are still interested in pursuing this request, please confirm your continued interest as soon as possible, but no later than September 20, 2024. Please be advised that if we do not hear from you within this time period, we will assume that you have elected not to pursue your request and it will be administratively closed. However, this does not in any way prohibit you from making FOIA requests in the future. An administrativeclosure does not prevent you from submitting future requests for the sameinformation. If you have any questions, please contact me at (202) 551-8353. Thank you for your cooperation and patience. Ronnye L. Hall [she/her] Lead Research Specialist Office of FOIA Services OFFICE  +1(202) 551-8353 hallr@sec.gov

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Texas LIHTC QCs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of all requests or applications for qualified contracts for LIHTC developments submitted to the Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs, including the following:

1) The year of the application or request
2) The projects's name, full address, and ownership
3) The qualified contract price
4) The total number of units covered
5) The outcome of the request and start and end dates of the deregulation period, if one ensued
6) Any information retained by the agency on the requester or applicant, including their name, contact information, and organizational affiliation

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rebecca Burns

communications.subject: RE: PIR - 8482 Texas Public Information Act Request: Texas LIHTC QCs
communications.communication:
Hello,

The Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs acknowledges receipt of your Public Information Request (PIR - 8482). Please note that TDHCA is only required to provide documentation that is readily available, it is not required to create documentation to fulfill a public information request.

Barring any need for clarification or additional time to produce the requested information, we will produce your requested information as soon as possible. Furthermore, we will notify you and provide an estimate if any charges apply to your request.

Your media contact moving forward for this PIR will be Kristina Tirloni.

Thank you.

Open Records Office
Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs
221 E. 11th Street | Austin, TX 78701
Fax: 512.469.9606

About TDHCA
The Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs administers a number of state and federal programs through for-profit, nonprofit, and local government partnerships to strengthen communities through affordable housing development, homeownership opportunities, weatherization, and community-based services for Texans in need. For more information, including current funding opportunities and information on local providers, please visit https://www.tdhca.texas.gov/. For more information about filing a Public Information Request (PIR) and the guidelines of the Texas Public Information Act (PIA), please visit https://www.tdhca.texas.gov/public-information-act.

Any person receiving guidance from TDHCA staff should be mindful that, as set forth in 10 TAC Section 11.1(b), there are important limitations and caveats (Also see 10 TAC §10.2(b)).

communications.subject: RE: Texas Public Information Act Request #PIR - 8482
communications.communication:
Hello:

Regarding PIR – 8482, we have determined that complying with your request will result in the imposition of a charge exceeding $40. Therefore, we are providing you with this cost estimate as required by section 552.2615 of the Texas Government Code.
Itemized List of Charges
Description
Qty x Price
Total
Labor hours ($15/hour)
18 x $15.00
$270.00
Overhead charges
20% of $270.00
$54.00
Total cost
$324.00


You also have the option to view the responsive information at our office. If you choose to view the information in person, we can set up a time that is convenient for you to come and view them. Please note, this may or may not decrease the cost of this request. Although for this particular request, it appears the charge and response time will remain the same.

The estimated charges exceed $100.00; therefore, as allowed by section 552.263(a) of the Government Code, we require a deposit of 50% ($162.00) before starting work on your request

Your request will be considered automatically withdrawn if you do not notify us in writing within ten business days (08/22/2024) from the date of this letter that you either:

  1.  (a) accept the estimate charges;
  2.  (b) wish to modify your request; OR
  3.  (c) have sent to the Open Records Division of the Office of the Attorney General a complaint alleging that you are being overcharged for the information you have requested.

Regards,

Open Records Office
Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs
221 E. 11th Street | Austin, TX 78701
Fax: 512.469.9606

About TDHCA
The Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs administers a number of state and federal programs through for-profit, nonprofit, and local government partnerships to strengthen communities through affordable housing development, homeownership opportunities, weatherization, and community-based services for Texans in need. For more information, including current funding opportunities and information on local providers, please visit https://www.tdhca.texas.gov/. communications.subject: Indiana Access to Public Records Act Request: Beverage Agreements
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Indiana Access to Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Agreements related to the beverage pouring, distribution, or sales on campus or in athletics venues or facilities, including any related exclusive marketing agreements for beverage brands in those areas.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kelly North

title: Refinery29 Media Request For Title IX Complaint Records

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Refinery29 Media Request For Title IX Complaint Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all Title IX complaints involving The University Of Vermont within the past 5 years.

In order to help to determine my status to assess fees, you should know that I am a representative of the news media affiliated with Refinery29 and Vice Media Group.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Molly Longman

communications.communication:
Good Afternoon,

This e-mail is in response to your request for a status on the subject FOIA requests: 22-00263-F

The Department receives an overwhelming amount of FOIA requests, some of which are complex and voluminous that requires a line-by-line review of hundreds or even thousands of pages of documents.  Requests are processed on a first-in-first-out basis. Your request is currently under processing review.

Please continue check on the status of your request on the Department’s FOIA Web page at http://www2.ed.gov/policy/gen/leg/foia/foiatoc.html and click on the Requests Status Log link under “More Resources.”

If you have any questions, please contact the FOIA Service Center at (202) 401-8365 or via e-mail at EDFOIAManager@ed.gov<mailto:EDFOIAManager@ed.gov>.
Thank You,



FOIA Service Center

communications.subject: FOIA Request, 22-00263-F
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,



I am currently in the process of reviewing your request and came across correspondence between yourself and regional staff in the OCR New York office. You agreed to amend your complaint to only include Title IX complaints against the specified universities involving sexual harassment, sexual violence and different treatment based on sex in athletic programs. Are you seeking complaints involving sexual harassment, sexual violence, and different treatment based on sex only in the context of athletic programs? Or are you seeking the complaints as your request is written (all Title IX complaints involving "sexual harassment", all Title IX complaints involving "sexual violence", and all Title IX complaints involving "different treatment based on sex only in athletic programs")?



Daniel McCusker | Government Information Specialist

FOIA Service Center | Office of the Secretary

U.S. Department of Education

400 Maryland Ave. SW

Washington, DC  20202-4510

FOIA Hotline (202) 401-8365

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Reopening enforcement
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

For the following records holders/custodians:

Sandra Lay
Peabo Welcome
Argentina Rodriguez
Rohan Russell
Adam Gittlitz
Hai Le
Crystal Leckie
Kwabena Nuamah


For the following terms:

proactive, 311, mask, distancing, soap, sanitizer, cleaning, screening, reopening, HVAC, thermometer, barrier, central air, ventilation, filtration, COVID, airborne, aerosol, respirator, n95, infection, safety, droplets

Between January 1, 2020, and January 1, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

ALEXANDER RICCIO

communications.communication: Ok, that's two days from now, and three days from when you responded. Is there any reason why I may not receive documents by that date?

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Riccio:

A search for records responsive to your request returned well over 18 GB of data.  According to industry estimates, 1 GB of data can contain anywhere from 16,000 individual pages to over 60,000 pages, depending on the type of document involved.  DOHMH must review all records for applicable exemptions under FOIL prior to release. Could you please modify the terms of your request so that we can identify a reasonable number of potentially responsive records?

Many thanks,
Bernadette

I have a gut feeling "reopening" and "distancing" are catching a huge dragnet because so many things fell under the cognitive umbrella of "distancing".

If *that* search is still massive, then a search for only (ventilation OR airborne OR n95 OR droplets)  is kinda acceptable if I bite my tongue, close my eyes, and stub my toe. 


I'd really rather not drop germs like "sanitizer" insofar as we went through several years of a predominantly airborne aerosol-inhalation-spread pandemic with authorities directing the general public to clean surfaces instead of the air.... So if you have the patience I'd really appreciate you trying the 7 term search first!!

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Excellent news!

I think the final step here is to run the same query but with 
size:1048568..1074000000

And briefly look at the files that come back


I'd recommend downloading a copy of all the files to your local machine and use software like WinDirStat to examine the numbers, types, and sizes, of the files that are greater than 1 MiB here. I'm guessing that a small number of files are responsible for the vast majority of file space, and I would like to discuss using a different page estimation for those files.


If that's too slow, I also am the author of a very popular fork of that program that's manyfold faster, it's called altWinDirStat. I wrote after getting frustrated with the slowness of WinDirStat 😅. Your IT department may discourage installing altWinDirStat because I never bothered to sign the executable.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Good morning,

I’m not sure I understand. Are you asking to me to run the search again with size:1048568..1074000000?

The other search was at the cusp of reasonableness, so if this search will expand the results, it will likely not be reasonable.
Thanks,
Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Kinda, yeah, but not exactly.

I'm suggesting you run the search again but only with that parameter returning larger files, with the intent of seeing how many files are of the kind that might fit the "1 GB of data can contain anywhere from 16,000 individual pages to over 60,000 pages" estimate. Using size:1048568..1074000000 returns all the results that are between about a megabyte and a gigabyte. I'm making an educated guess that a very small number of files are responsible for the majority of the on disk space.

I suspect that some files are very large on disk (like powerpoints with uncompressed images), but have very few pages that need to be reviewed. As an example, a scientist colleague of mine once had a powerpoint presentation that was more than a gigabyte in size, with something like only 50 slides. She'd included some videos that had never been compressed, which drastically inflated the file size.

I do not know exactly what features the city pays for (the licensing agreement with Microsoft is the subject of another ongoing FOIL request of mine!), but one possible option is you may be able to export a report to see more information about the documents the search returns:
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/ediscovery-export-a-content-search-report

An alternative that I provided was to simply download a copy of the larger search results and spot check them to see if there are just a few files that account for the majority of the on-disk space. That's very easy with some common free software, but if you wish to do it manually, increasing the parameter to something like size:52430000..1074000000 should reduce the volume of files even further.

I'd expect that using size:1048568..1074000000 might return several hundred files, and size:52430000..1074000000 might return a few dozen. If you run the 50 MB-1GB search and the size of the responsive records are like 10GB, that means we've found the culprit! And I can ask you to either review the number of pages in that files when estimating the voluminousness of the request as a whole. If it's just a few powerpoints, neither of us have to worry about days  spent redacting 16,000 pages, it may only be a hundred.

communications.subject: RE: [EXTERNAL] RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Hi Alexander,

I appreciate your interest in the ediscovery process, and I hear what you are saying. I think for the purposes of FOIL, this really goes beyond what the statute requires.  I would propose we stick with the search that I identified as reasonable. In the alternative, I can provide you with instructions on how to submit an administrative appeal of this determination.

Please let me know.
Thanks,
Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication: That's ok then, let's go with the search you identified as reasonable.

Thanks very much,
Bernadette

communications.subject: RE: New York Freedom of Information Law Request #2023FR02174
communications.communication:
Hello there, we are approaching three missed agency-proposed records production dates. Will the August 16, 2024 agency-proposed records production date/deadline most recently proposed by the agency be met?

I would like to assume the agency is being forthright with me about meeting a date they propose, and have no knowledge of anything that they might be able to reasonably foresee preventing them from producing the requested and agreed upon records. I struggle to fathom how a pre-existing and ongoing backlog could surprise anybody by causing delays in records production - some agencies have abused this with me in a downright rude manner to delay requests more than a dozen times. 

I have no personal animus with any individual employed by the department - in a likely understaffed role - who is following routine agency procedures, and I presume they have no issue with me. We're all working with unfair systems run by people we have no contact with! Indeed, the records access officer I dealt with earlier was exceptionally helpful and more technically competent than the majority of records access officers that I've interacted with.

Over the years I have learned that such agency-proposed records production dates are more often missed than met, and it's no more likely the agency will meet the next date they propose than the one they've missed. On muckrock, this agency is a bit better than the average NYC agency, and returns records with an average of 113 days, so we're just on the edge of meeting this date! That's good news - I just want to rely on something better than crossed fingers.

I am pre-emptively appealing on grounds of constructive denial of records. I am asking the agency to provide guarantees that the August 16, 2024 agency-proposed records production date/deadline most recently proposed by the agency will be met, and if it cannot be met under current circumstances, that the agency shall either provide a date for which they will provide such records absent circumstances a reasonable person cannot reasonably forsee delaying production of records, or assign sufficient staff to meet the agency proposed records production date. 

I look forward to this appeal being moot upon production of records by the August 16, 2024 agency-proposed records production date.

communications.subject: Biscom DOHMH Delivery Data Servicestk@publishmeasap.com
communications.communication:
An account was requested on your behalf Samantha Bynoe by New York City Department of Health.



Your account has been created and you should receive an email with the credentials. Attached here is a small guide to help you along.



This service is used to send and/or receive files from/to an employee at the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.







DOHMH Data Delivery Service User Guide



This guide is an introduction to using the DOHMH Delivery Service (DDS) also known as Biscom.  DDS enables the secure delivery of files, documents and other electronic information while providing tracking and reporting capabilities.





DDS secure file transfer involves three simple steps:

1.   Create a package of files and deliver it to a pre-approved external email address.

2.   Recipients are notified of their secure delivery in an email message.

(Recipients must have an account in this system otherwise they will not be able to get files)

3.   Recipient signs into DDS, retrieves the package and downloads the file(s).





Definitions

Package: A file or collection of files uploaded to the DDS system.

Delivery: An email that links recipients to a package - packages that are created can be delivered.

Express Delivery: A way for Senders to upload files and deliver them in a single step (package creation and delivery are combined).

Sender: A user who has been approved to send files to one or more recipients.

Recipient: A authorized user who can receive files and reply to deliveries but cannot send their own files.





Logging in for the First time:



  1.  You will receive an email with the credentials from notify@a816-healthpsi.nyc.gov<mailto:notify@a816-healthpsi.nyc.gov> and the link that will take you to the login page.

That link is to always be used when using this system, so please bookmark it.



  1.  The email will look like the image below. Click on the link in the email to get the login page.

Enter your username and password.

Please note: Do not copy and paste the password, please type in each character



[cid:image001.jpg@01D91078.8B89BCC0]





  1.  Once logged in you will be immediately asked to change your password.

Once done you will be asked to re-login using the new password.



This is the policy for accounts:

If an account is inactive for 45 days, it will automatically be expired.

First inactivity warning is 14 days prior; Second inactivity warning is 7 days prior.

You must login at least once every 45 days to keep your account active.



This is the policy for passwords:

Password is valid for 90 days

Password Expiration warning is sent 7 days prior

Passwords must contain at least one of each



              The password must meet these requirements. It must have a least one from each a section:

                                           Uppercase letters:                               A - Z

Lowercase letters:                               a - z

Digits:                                                    0 - 9

Non-alphanumeric characters:     ~ , < , { , + ,  etc.

Password must be at minimum 8 characters (maximum is 50 characters)



  1.  Please setup your security questions which helps in case you forget your password.

You can do this by clicking on Personal settings on the top right of the screen then selecting Edit Profile

You will see the Fields for Password reset Question please enter your question and answer, then select update.



            Please note: You cannot reuse the same password you previously had.





Instructions for Sending Files:



To send one or more files, you must have the Sender role assigned to you. As a Sender, you will see the

 Express Delivery icon and link in the main menu.



[cid:image002.png@01D91078.8B89BCC0]





  1.  Click this link or icon to open the delivery screen.





[cid:image003.png@01D91078.8B89BCC0]



2.  Enter the email addresses of your recipients in the To field

3.   Enter a subject or topic in the Subject field.

4.   Drag and drop files into the files box or click the Add file button to open a file chooser dialog.

5.   Optional: enter a secure message.

6.   Optional: Click the Show options link to expand the delivery and enter an email notification message, and additional delivery options.

7.   Click the Send button to upload your files and send an email notification message to the recipients.





Replying to a Delivery:

Recipients can reply to a secure delivery they've received by clicking on the Show/Hide Reply Section link at the bottom of the delivery. A secure message and one or more files can be sent back to the original sender of the message.



Retrieving Files:

Recipients of secure deliveries receive a non-secure email in their email inbox. This email contains a notification message and an embedded hyperlink. Clicking the hyperlink will bring the recipient to the DDS application sign-in page, and once the recipient provides their username and password, the recipient will have access to their delivery.



Notice:

This secure data transfer system is the property of the NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and is intended for business purposes only. You have no right to privacy on the system, and all information and activity on the system may be monitored.  Any illegal or unauthorized use of the system may result in disciplinary action and/or civil or criminal penalties.

Your use of the system constitutes express consent to the above terms and conditions.









Regards, Tyler Bennett.

Sent from the New York City Department of Health & Mental Hygiene. This email and any files transmitted with it may contain confidential information and are intended solely for the use of the individual or entity to whom they are addressed. This footnote also confirms that this email message has been swept for the presence of computer viruses.

communications.subject: FOIL Control No. 2023FR02147 response
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Riccio:

My apologies for the delay.  The NYC Department of Health grants your Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) request with the above-referenced control number. Based on the size of the response file, records will be sent to you shortly via BISCOM. If you have issues with opening the file, please let me know.

Records have been withheld for the following reasons:

  1.  they are inter-agency or intra-agency materials pursuant to FOIL §87(2)(g); or
  2.  their disclosure would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy pursuant to FOIL §§ 87(2)(b) and 89(2)(b); or
  3.  they are exempt from disclosure pursuant to FOIL §87(2)(a); or
  4.  their disclosure would jeopardize the capacity of the Health Department to guarantee the security of its information technology assets pursuant to FOIL §87(2)(i).

In addition, redactions were made to records which were not responsive to your request.

You may file a written appeal of this determination within 30 days of the date of this message.  The appeal should be addressed to:
Chari Anhouse
Associate General Counsel and Records Access Appeals Officer
Email: recordsaccess@health.nyc.gov<mailto:recordsaccess@health.nyc.gov>

The notice of appeal should include the request control number, the date of this message, a description of the records that were the subject of the request, the specific legal grounds for your appeal, and the full name and email address of the original requester.

Sincerely,


Bernadette O'Donnell
Records Access Officer / Associate General Counsel
Office of the General Counsel
NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene - City of New York
42-09 28th St., Long Island City, NY 11101
Email: bodonnell1@health.nyc.gov<mailto:bodonnell1@health.nyc.gov> | nyc.gov/health<https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/index.page>

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: staff list
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

a complete list of DHCR employees, including name, title, salary, and length of employment
a complete list of DHCR vacancies, including title, salary, and date of the vacancy's beginning

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sam Mellins

New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) submits the following response to your request dated July 11, 2023 for: 
"To Whom It May Concern: 

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records: 

a complete list of DHCR employees, including name, title, salary, and length of employment 
a complete list of DHCR vacancies, including title, salary, and date of the vacancy's beginning 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Sincerely, 

Sam Mellins

communications.subject: Welcome to the City of Chicago Request Center!

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Bernadette Feazell

Attached are reports for payroll disbursements to Johnathan Crawley.  The report includes the funding source of the disbursement and no disbursements were made from Federal funds.  
Thank you,
Frances Bartlett

title: Maryland on the job death claims (Maryland Occupational Safety And Health (mosh) - Division Of Labor And Industry)

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Maryland on the job death claims (Maryland Occupational Safety And Health (mosh) - Division Of Labor And Industry)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any investigative reports /incident reports concerning on-the-job deaths reported in the State of Maryland between January 1, 2020 and Dec 31, 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Wesley Lowery

communications.subject: Re: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Maryland on the job death claims (Maryland Occupational Safety And Health (mosh) - Division Of Labor And Industry)
communications.communication:
Hello,

Thank you for the email. In the future, please send public information act
requests to mosh.mpia@maryland.gov. The email address has been copied on
this response.

Thank you,

[image: Maryland Department of Labor]
Maryland Occupational Safety and Health (MOSH)
Maryland Department of Labor
10946 Golden West Drive, Suite 160
Hunt Valley, MD 21031
mosh.complaints@maryland.gov
410-527-4499 (O)
410-527-4488 (F)
Website <https://www.labor.maryland.gov/> | Facebook
<https://www.facebook.com/MarylandLabor> | Twitter
<https://twitter.com/MD_Labor>

Click here to complete a three-question customer experience survey
<http://www.doit.state.md.us/selectsurvey/TakeSurvey.aspx?agencycode=DLLR&SurveyID=86M2956>

Confidentiality Notice. The information contained in this communication
(including any attachments) (a) is or may be legally privileged,
confidential, proprietary in nature, or otherwise protected by law from
disclosure; and (b) is intended only for the use of the addressee(s) named
herein. If you are not the intended recipient, an addressee, or the person
responsible for delivering this to an addressee, you are hereby notified
that reading, using, copying, or distributing any part of this message is
strictly prohibited. If you have received this electronic mail message in
error, please contact me immediately and take the steps necessary to delete
the message completely from your computer system. Thank you.

We recently received a PIA request for Any investigative/incident reports concerning on the job deaths reported in the State of Maryland between January 1, 2020 through December 31, 2023.  I would like to request clarification of this request.  Are you asking for work related fatalities where an inspection was conducted, or are you looking for all fatalities reported to MOSH (i.e. are you wanting information that turned out not to be work-related like heart attacks and motor vehicle accidents where no inspection was conducted)?

This type of request is going to take considerable time and there maybe a fee involved due to the amount of background investigative efforts.  Once further clarification is received, we can than advise of the fee and proceed with this request.  Please send reply to mosh.mpia@maryland.gov.

Thank you

Victoria Flowers

communications.subject: Re: Maryland Public Information Act Request #Log 24-052
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon,

In response to your recent MPIA request received on April 5, 2024, we can
provide you with 26 case files between the dates of January 1, 2020 and
December 31, 2023 within the next 2 weeks.  There are an additional 69 case
files we can provide between those dates and our fee for that information
will be $2,156.25.

Should this fee be acceptable, please respond by Friday April 12, 2024.  We
can provide you with an invoice and payment form and once payment has been
received, we can begin gathering the additional case files for you.

Thank You,

communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Lowery,

MOSH received your payment of $2,156.25 for the additional 69 investigation
reports related to job deaths which occurred in the State of Maryland
between January 1, 2020 and December 31, 2023.

 MOSH will begin review and preparation of the records for release.  MOSH
anticipates this will take several weeks.   Please let me know if you have
any questions.

-- 
Thank You,

communications.subject: Log 24-052 MPIA Request (see attachment for release letter)
communications.communication:
Dear Requester ,


   You should receive an email from Taxtran from “Victoria Flowers” which
will include your files from your MPIA request for records related to
Request 24-052 received on July 19, 2024.

     Attached with this email you will find a release letter.  Due to the
large volume of requested files and resources necessary to prepare the
files for release, MOSH will be providing the requested records in batches
every 10 to 12 days until the requested is completed.
If MOSH can be of further assistance, please do not hesitate to contact us
at mosh.mpia@maryland.gov.



-- 
Thank You,

communications.subject: New Package Notification
communications.communication:
New Package Notification

A package has been posted for you.

"Dear Requester,

Pursuant to your Maryland Public Information Act (MPIA) request, the records you requested are now available. In accordance with the MPIA, Part III and IV of the General Provisions Article (“GP”), Annotated Code, §4-101 et seq., the following information has been withheld:

Personal identifying information including home addresses and personal cell phone numbers of employees have been redacted for privacy reasons. 

Attorney client privilege.  This information is privileged and confidential under GP §4-301.

Should you disagree with the withholding of the above-listed information, the following remedies are available:

 1. You may pursue judicial enforcement remedies by filing a complaint with the Circuit Court in accordance with GP §4-362. 


 2.   In addition, Pursuant to GP § 4-362, you are entitled to seek judicial review of this decision. Alternatively, you may file a request for mediation with the Public Access Ombudsman and, if the Ombudsman is unable to resolve the matter, may subsequently seek a resolution from the Public Information Act Compliance Board for those matters within the Compliance Board's jurisdiction.  See GP §§ 4-1A-01 et seq. and 4-1B-01 et seq.

  

Due to the large volume of requested  files  and resources necessary to prepare the files for release, MOSH will be providing the requested records in batches every 10 to 12 days until the request is completed.


If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us at mosh.mpia@maryland.gov.


Sincerely,


Victoria Flowers

Administrative Assistant

Division of Labor and Industry

Maryland Department of Labor

10946 Golden West Drive | Suite 160

Hunt Valley, Maryland 21031

Victoria.Flowers@maryland.gov

410-527-2076 phone"

title: Code Enforcement's Refusal to Enforce Laws Requiring Deadbolts at the Baltimore Hotel owned by-AIDS Healthcare Foundation

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Code Enforcement's Refusal to Enforce Laws Requiring Deadbolts at the Baltimore Hotel owned by-AIDS Healthcare Foundation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide all notes, entries, photos, videos, reports, complaints, emails, text messages, and other communications, concerning the following:

1.Code Enforcement Complaint #897099, filed April 30, 2024, in which a tenant complained he did not have a deadbolt, and more than 100 other units at the AIDS Healthcare Foundation's Baltimore Hotel did not have deadbolts
2. Inspector Tony Robles noted that on May 9, 2024, he went to the Baltimore and spoke with the complaining tenant, and took photos.  Please provide all of those notes, documents, photos or videos.
3. All communications regarding the February 2022 inspection by Tony Robles of the Baltimore, during which he noted over 100 violations for lack of deadbolts, but James Heiberg said to delete those violations. 
4. All communications between anyone from Code Enforcement and anyone at AIDS Healthcare Foundation, regarding the deadbolts at the Baltimore.  This is including but not limited to the text messages and emails that Robert Gilardi kindly sends to Mark Dyer rather than issuing a Notice to Comply. This includes communications between Code Enforcement on the one hand, and on the other hand,  AHF's: Mark Dyer, Michael Weinstein, Jonathan Eisenberg, Tom Myers, Conrad Sison, Beatrice Di Marco, Dominique Eastman, Herbert Ellis,  Juan Larios.
5. Any discussion (including emails, text messages, memos, notes) between any Code Enforcement employee, (including but not limited to James Heiberg, Robert Gilardi, Tony Robles, Ann Sewill, etc.), that includes any of the following terms: "1941.3" "deadbolt" "dead bolt" "91.8607" "door lock" "91.8607" and/or "897099." 
6. Any discussion between any Code Enforcement employee, about why it decided to exclude the exact complaint language from the publicly accessible Property Activity Report on complaint #897099.
7. Any emails with the subject line "Complaint # 897099 / Baltimore Hotel / Carlos Brum/ Lack of Deadbolts"

This public records act request is not limited to the custodian of records simply forwarding this request to the named individuals here. This request demands that the custodian of records actually contact its IT department and conduct a search with the specific parameters and search terms. This request demands electronic copies of these records in their native format, and not printed out and scanned.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Annette Morasch

communications.communication: If I do not get a meaningful and substantive response by July 26, I will engage an attorney to file a petition for writ of mandate to compel compliance. Obtaining documents through a writ opens up the City to paying for the prevailing party's attorneys' fees and costs. The response was due a month ago and I have not received a single document.

communications.subject: RE: California Public Records Act Request #43412
communications.communication:
These records do not include any of the attachments to the emails. As just one example, the email from Mark Dyer to the City dated 2/12/2024 has several attachments which were not produced. (See attached.) None of the emails which show they have attachments were produced with the attachments. 
These records also do not include any of the following requested documents:

2. Inspector Tony Robles noted that on May 9, 2024, he went to the Baltimore and spoke with the complaining tenant, and took photos. Please provide all of those notes, documents, photos or videos.
3. All communications regarding the February 2022 inspection by Tony Robles of the Baltimore, during which he noted over 100 violations for lack of deadbolts, but James Heiberg said to delete those violations.
4. All communications between anyone from Code Enforcement and anyone at AIDS Healthcare Foundation, regarding the deadbolts at the Baltimore. This is including but not limited to the text messages and emails that Robert Gilardi kindly sends to Mark Dyer rather than issuing a Notice to Comply. This includes communications between Code Enforcement on the one hand, and on the other hand, AHF's: Mark Dyer, Michael Weinstein, Jonathan Eisenberg, Tom Myers, Conrad Sison, Beatrice Di Marco, Dominique Eastman, Herbert Ellis, Juan Larios.
5. Any discussion (including emails, text messages, memos, notes) between any Code Enforcement employee, (including but not limited to James Heiberg, Robert Gilardi, Tony Robles, Ann Sewill, etc.), that includes any of the following terms: "1941.3" "deadbolt" "dead bolt" "91.8607" "door lock" "91.8607" and/or "897099."

Documents have been redacted without reason. I understand why you woudl redact tenant contact information (which you did for some, but not others). But there are whole chunks of communications redacted without saying who was involved in the redacted communication. Thus the majority of my requests were ignored by the  City. 

Conclusion. If I do not receive a fully compliant response to my PRA, we will file a writ of mandate and seek attorneys' fees on August 19, 2024.

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Truancy Letter, Notices
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Per the CPS Comprehensive Policy on Attendance (Section 703.1, Board Report 22-0622-PO1), Section II, paragraph B (a):

"Schools must send a letter notifying a student’s family of 5 unexcused absences, and, subsequently, 10 unexcused absences. 10 day letters of unexcused absence notification are to be sent certified, return receipt requested."

In FOIA N014933-022924, the District indicates, "Be advised that while there is a system in place that advises schools of students who have had 5-day and 10-day unexcused absences, the correspondence that is to be sent out to parents is the responsibility of individual schools."

1. Provide a blank template letter for the 5 day unexcused absence letter;
2. Provide a blank template letter for the 10 day unexcused absence letter;
3. Provide records sufficient to show copies of 5 Days Unexcused Absence letters issued in SY 2023/2024;
4. Provide records sufficient to show copies of 10 Days Unexcused Absence letters issued in SY 2023/2024.

Please note that I am not seeking any personally identifiable information or otherwise exempt information. As required by the statute, please ensure that the requested documents are redacted rather than exempting the entirety of the document. Additionally, for any and all exemptions used to redact exempt information, please provide clear and convincing evidence for each exemption used by your agency.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. Copies of video recordings have a fee of $48. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.
